PROGESTERONE

  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Renal impairment
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Cautions
  • Less suitable for prescribing
  • Medicinal forms

Advice when patient is pregnant

Not known to be harmful.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Avoid in hepatic impairment.

Avoid in active liver disease including disorders of hepatic excretion (e.g. Dublin-Johnson or Rotor Syndromes), infective hepatitis (until liver function returns to normal) and liver tumours.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Use with caution.

Contra indications

  • Acute porphyrias
  • avoid in patients with a history of liver tumours
  • breast cancer (unless progestogens are being used in the management of this condition)
  • genital cancer (unless progestogens are being used in the management of this condition)
  • history during pregnancy of idiopathic jaundice
  • history during pregnancy of pemphigoid gestationis
  • history during pregnancy of severe pruritus
  • incomplete miscarriage
  • missed miscarriage
  • severe arterial disease
  • undiagnosed vaginal bleeding

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Acne, alopecia, anaphylactoid reactions, bloating, breast tenderness, change in libido, depression, dizziness, drowsiness, fluid retention, headache, hirsutism, insomnia, jaundice, menstrual disturbances, nausea, premenstrual-like syndrome, pruritus, rash, skin reactions, urticaria, weight change,

Specific side effects

notKnown: injection-site reactions, diarrhoea, flatulence, pain, injection-site reactions, local irritation,

Directions for administration

With oral use

Capsules should be taken at bedtime on an empty stomach.

Advice for patients and carers

With oral use

Patient counselling is advised for progesterone capsules (administration).

Cautions regarding administration

  • Asthma
  • cardiac dysfunction
  • conditions that may worsen with fluid retention
  • diabetes (progestogens can decrease glucose tolerance—monitor patient closely)
  • epilepsy
  • history of depression
  • hypertension
  • migraine
  • susceptibility to thromboembolism (particular caution with high dose)

Conditions when less suitable for prescribing

With vaginal use

Progesterone pessaries are less suitable for prescribing.

Prepared medicinal forms of PROGESTERONE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: cream,
Capsule
Solution for injection
Pessary
Vaginal gel
